titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jon Lewis Photographs of the United Farm Workers Movement
Lewis (Jon) Photographs of the United Farm Workers Movement
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:23

did.unittitle: Jon Lewis photographs of the United Farm Workers movement

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: This collection consists of approximately eleven thousand photographs created by Jon Lewis that document the activities of César Chávez, the National Farm Workers Association, and United Farm Workers Organizing Committee in California, 1966-1971, as well as related publications and audiovisual materials, including videotapes and videodiscs, 1967-2009. Most images document activities related to the California Grape Strike in 1966.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Gaylord Jon Lewis on the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 2009-2010.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Jon Lewis Photographs of the United Farm Workers Movement is the physical property of The Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University, also retains any and all copyrights in the Jon Lewis Photographs of the United Farm Workers Movement collection and full authority to control commercial use of materials in it. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jon Lewis Photographs of the United Farm Workers Movement. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Jon Lewis, Photographs and Film of César Chávez and Agricultural Labor Activities in California (WA Photos 81). Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Jon Lewis (1938-2009)
bioghist.p: Gaylord Jon Lewis (1938-2009) was a photographer and printer in San Francisco, California. After service in the United States Marine Corps, Lewis earned a baccalaureate degree from San Jose State University. In 1966, Lewis joined the farm worker movement and documented the work and activities of César Chávez and the California Grape Strike. He later earned a graduate degree in photography at San Francisco State University.

bioghist.head: United Farm Workers of America and the California Grape Strike
bioghist.p: The United Farm Workers of America (UFWA) is a labor union created from the merging of the Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee (AWOC) led by Larry Itliong (1913-1977), Philip Vera Cruz (1904-1994), and others, with the National Farm Workers Association (NFWA) led by César Chávez (1927-1993) and Dolores Huerta (born 1930).

On September 8, 1965, the AWOC and its primarily Filipino membership started a strike against grape growers in Delano, California. During the strike they demanded salaries equal to the federal minimum wage. The predominantly Mexican-American NFWA joined the strike soon after it began. During the California Grape Strike and related boycott of table grapes, the AWOC and NFWA recognized their common goals and methods. On August 22, 1966, the groups combined to form the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee and became a member of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. The union eventually became the United Farm Workers of America. By 1970, the UFWA reached a collective bargaining agreement with the table-grape growers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of approximately eleven thousand photographs created by Jon Lewis that document the activities of César Chávez, the National Farm Workers Association, and United Farm Workers Organizing Committee in California, 1966-1971, as well as related publications and audiovisual materials, 1967-2009. Most images document activities related to the California Grape Strike in 1966.

Images include migrant agricultural laborers during the picketing fields of table grape growers, including the Di Giorgio Fruit Corporation, in Delano, California, during the California Grape Strike. Other images related to the strikers depict the labor of farm workers, their housing, and the vineyards. A group of images depicts strikers picketing the arrival of Governor Edmund Gerald "Pat" Brown, Sr. at the meeting of the California Democratic Council in Bakersfield, California, February 1966. A significant group of images documents a visit to strikers by Senator Robert F. Kennedy in March 1966, as well as a related local hearing for the Senate Subcommittee on Migratory Labor that he conducted with Senators Harrison A. Williams and George L. Murphy in Delano. Groups of images also document college student volunteers supporting the strike during the summer of 1966.

Many images document a peregrinación (pilgrimage) march during the California Grape Strike from Delano to Sacramento, March-April 1966, including informal portraits of César Chávez; views of marchers and flag bearers holding flags for the National Farm Workers Association; and images of a banner that depicts the Catholic icon of the Virgin Mary known as Our Lady of Guadalupe. Related images to the peregrinación show volunteers and activities that provided material support for the march, including food caravans and temporary camps, as well as rallies held along the route of the march.

A substantial portion of images in the collection document performances of El Teatro Campesino, a theatrical troupe founded by Luis Valdez and Agustin Lira, which performed as a cultural arm of the National Farm Workers Association.

A small group of images depict César Chávez at an outdoor religious service during his Fast for Nonviolence at the Field Office of the United Farm Workers of America in Delano, also known as "Forty Acres," February-March 1968.

Few individuals involved with the strike are identified in the images. Individuals identified in the collection include César Chávez and his wife, Helen Chávez, as well as other members of the union leadership, including James L. Drake, Marshall Ganz, Dolores Huerta, Larry Itliong, Antonio Orendain, Gilbert Padilla, and Fred Ross.

Besides documenting the activities of the groups and individuals, the photographic material in the collection documents the evolution of images from negatives captured by Lewis to resultant prints and publications. The negatives and contact sheets show variant images captured by Lewis. The books and audiovisual materials document the in which ways Lewis and others used the images.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Photographs, 1966-1971. II. Books and Audiovisual Materials, 1967-2009.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into six subseries: Portfolios, Black and White Photographic Prints, Contact Prints, Negatives, Color Photographic Prints, and Color Slides.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographs created by Lewis that depict the activities of the National Farm Workers Association, 1966-1971. The photographs are chiefly black and white, but include a small portion of color images, which Lewis also printed in black and white. Many images are duplicated across the various subseries.

Many of the photographic prints in the Portfolios and Black and White Photographic Prints subseries have numbers written in pencil on their versos that reference the negative rolls for the original images, which are available in the Negative subseries, as well as their corresponding contact sheets in the Contact Sheets subseries. The sequence of these rolls within each subseries follow a roughly chronological arrangement.

Some photographic prints in the Portfolios and Black and White Photographic Prints subseries also have pencil inscriptions of filenames written in pencil on their versos that reference digital surrogates created by the Farmworker Movement Documentation Project. CD-ROMS with these digital surrogates are in Series II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Groups of chiefly black and white photographic prints compiled by Lewis based on their general subject matter under titles applied by Lewis.

did.unittitle: Boycott Di Giorgio Fruit Corporation March in San Francisco, California
Di Giorgio Fruit Corporation Phony Election
Di Giorgio Fruit Corporation Election Organizing
Di Giorgio Fruit Corporation Election Rally and Food Caravan from Sacramento to Delano
Volunteers and Picketing Governor Edmund Gerald "Pat" Brown, Sr. in Bakersfield, California

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Based on a preliminary comparison with the photographic negatives, the prints are arranged sequentially by negative roll number, followed by prints from unnumbered rolls, then by prints which were not matched to negatives, and then by oversize photographic prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most prints are 8 by 10 inches in size. The images chiefly derive from rolls in the Negatives subseries, while some photographic prints derive from color slides, which are in the available in the Color Slides subseries.
Many of the images have duplicate prints. Identified prints without pencil inscriptions on their verso have been filed with their corresponding roll number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Each folder holds a single image. Many images have many duplicate prints.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged sequentially by roll number followed by sheets from unnumbered rolls.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Black and white contact prints of 35 millimeter negatives created and compiled by Lewis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The numbering for rolls is repeated in this box. This includes two rolls for each of the numbers 257, 259, and 262, as well as three rolls with the number 260.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The numbering for rolls is repeated in this box. This includes two rolls at each of the numbers 286 and 291.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged sequentially by roll number followed by unnumbered rolls.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chiefly black and white negatives created and compiled by Lewis. Lewis often spliced negatives from different sequences of original images together into discrete "rolls."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Roll 33 includes sixteen color negatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The numbering for rolls is repeated in this box. This includes two rolls for each of the numbers 259, 260, 262, and 286.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of color photographic prints that range in size from four by six inches to twelve by eighteen inches.
Some images are duplicated in the subseries Color Slides.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged with a slide show compiled by Lewis, followed by color slides with printed dates on their mounts, and then color slides arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists chiefly of color thirty-five millimeter slides. Some images are duplicated in the subseries Color Photographic Prints, as well as the subseries Black and White Photographic Prints.

did.unittitle: Slide show, "Hasta Sacramento . . . : The 1966 Peregrinación as Seen by Jon Lewis"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accompanied by photographic prints of the slide show.

did.unittitle: Copy Photograph of the Our Lady of Guadalupe icon

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into two subseries: Books and Audiovisual Materials by Lewis and Materials by Others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of publications and audiovisual materials created by Lewis and others that used his photographs.

did.unittitle: Books and Audiovisual Materials by Lewis

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by the first date of publication of the material by Lewis.

unittitle.title: La Huelga De La Uva En Delano: The Strike of the Grape in Delano
From This Earth ... of the Delano Grape Strike

did.unittitle: Covers, title page, and advertisement clipping

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses creating a digital version of the book for Luis Valdez.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The documentary film Nosotros Venceremos (We shall overcome) with the opening title of "La huelga de la uva en Delano" (The strike of the grape in Delano) was produced by Lewis in 1971 and was used as a promotional tool by the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee.

The film documents the events of 1966 using photographic imagery that depicts picket lines, individual farm workers, the peregrinación march from Delano to Sacramento, the Fast for Nonviolence by Chávez, and the announcement of a contract between the union and growers with a soundtrack of hymns and speeches in Spanish recorded by Eliezer Lozada Risco.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by the first date of publication of the material.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Rodrigo Terronez Memorial Clinic is a medical clinic for farm workers in Delano, California, operated by the United Farm Workers of America.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Founded in 2003 by LeRoy Chatfield, the Farmworker Movement Documentation Project compiles and publishes primary source accounts from the volunteers who worked with César Chávez to build his farm worker movement from 1962 to 1993.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: CD-ROMS with digital surrogates of photographs created by Lewis and used by the project in publications and its web site.

did.unittitle: Ink jet prints from digital surrogates
Songs of the Farmworker Movement (Hermosa Beach, Calif.: Sand Flea Studios) [Sound Recording]
Bill Brummel Productions, Viva La Causa: The Story of César Chávez and a Great Movement for Social Justice (Montgomery, Alabama: Teaching Tolerance)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This documentary film uses contemporary footage and dramatic reenactments to depict the grape strike and boycott.
